questions.question_text: What is the gRPC Network Management Interface protocol?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Correct answer: C

 gNMI uses the gRPC framework to enable telemetry and configuration management of devices. 

https://infohub.delltechnologies.com/l/enterprise-sonic-distribution-by-dell-technologies-lifecycle-management/grpc-network-management-interface

Selected Answer: C
C is correct:
gRPC Network Management Interface (gNMI) is a Google Protocol RPC (gRPC) based protocol to manage network devices. gRPC is a framework used to connect services competently. SONiC provides the gNMI server, while the user provides the client. gNMI uses the gRPC framework to enable telemetry and configuration management of devices. gNMI streams data from the network device and provides the functionality to configure and retrieve operational and configuration states while providing a powerful method for switch management. The use of gNMI for the streaming of data from the network device and the functionality to configure and retrieve operational and configuration states provides a powerful method for switch management.
https://infohub.delltechnologies.com/l/enterprise-sonic-distribution-by-dell-technologies-lifecycle-management/grpc-network-management-interface

Selected Answer: C
gNMI
Support for config management and telemetry dial-in
Source: https://www.ciscolive.com/c/dam/r/ciscolive/emea/docs/2019/pdf/DEVWKS-1381.pdf
This is C.

comments.content:
Never mind, 
The DELL doc is clear in this.
gNMI uses the gRPC framework to enable telemetry and configuration management of devhttps://www.examtopics.com/exams/cisco/350-901/view/36/#ices.

discussion.content:
I would think A.
a unified management protocol for streaming telemetry (to Telegraf) and database logging (Influxdb)

choices.A: a unified management protocol for streaming telemetry and database logging
choices.B: a configuration management protocol for monitoring
choices.D: a logging protocol used across database servers
choices.C: a protocol for configuration management and streaming telemetry

questions.question_text: Which two gRPC modes of model-driven telemetry are supported on Cisco IOS XE Software? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
Correct answers: A & B

Selected Answer: AB
A and B are correct. 
dial-out = static while dial-in is dynamic
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/prog/configuration/1612/b_1612_programmability_cg/model_driven_telemetry.html

A&B are the correct answers

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/prog/configuration/1612/b_1612_programmability_cg/model_driven_telemetry.html
C is correct
duplicate, but here it states YANG model, while in the other it told "YAML model", which lead to misinterpretation. Maybe the other question is worded incorrectly ?

Selected Answer: C
Duplicate question.
Correct answer: C

questions.question_text:
A heterogeneous network of vendors and device types needs automating for better efficiency and to enable future automated testing. The network consists of switches, routers, firewalls, and load balancers from different vendors; however, they all support the NETCONF/RESTCONF configuration standards and the
YANG models with every feature the business requires. The business is looking for a buy versus build solution because they cannot dedicate engineering resources, and they need configuration diff and rollback functionality from day 1.
Which configuration management or automation tooling is needed for this solution?

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which RESTCONF verb changes the GigabitEthernet2 interface from 192.168.100.1/24 to 10.10.10.1/24?

discussion.content: B is correct

Selected Answer: B
Correcft answer: B 

Patch = update
Post = create or operation like reload

GET = Read
PATCH = Update
PUT = Create or Replace
POST = Create or Operations (reload, default)
DELETE = Deletes the targeted resource
HEAD = Header metadata (no response body)

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/prog/configuration/168/b_168_programmability_cg/RESTCONF.pdf

Selected Answer: B
B is correct since the question is asking to change an existing value (from 192.168.100.1/24 to 10.10.10.1/24)
The following table shows how the RESTCONF operations relate to NETCONF protocol operations:
GET = Read
PATCH = Update
PUT = Create or Replace
POST = Create or Operations (reload, default)
DELETE = Deletes the targeted resource
HEAD = Header metadata (no response body)

Selected Answer: B
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/prog/configuration/168/b_168_programmability_cg/RESTCONF.pdf

Selected Answer: B
POST creates new records.
PUT/PATCH updates/partially-updates existing records (meaning it performs a CHANGE).
Since the question wants to CHANGE a value on something that exists, than it can only be B - PATCH
I agree with PATCH because of the Cisco Study Guide DEVCOR 350-901

Selected Answer: B
Regarding to the Cisco DEVCOR 350-091 Study Guide Page 138, the Answer should be B. PATCH.

HTTPs Methods
The https-based protocol-RESTCONF (RFC 8040), which is a stateless protocol, uses secure HTTP methods
to provide CREATE, READ, UPDATE and DELETE (CRUD) operations on a conceptual datastore containing
YANG-defined data, which is compatible with a server that implements NETCONF datastores.
The following table shows how the RESTCONF operations relate to NETCONF protocol operations:
OPTIONS SUPPORTED METHODS
GET Read
PATCH Update
PUT Create or Replace
POST Create or Operations (reload, default)
DELETE Deletes the targeted resource
HEAD Header metadata (no response body)

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/prog/configuration/166/b_166_programmability_cg/restconf_prog_int.pdf

I would go with:
1. ietf:interfaces:interfaces
2. interface
3. Basic..
4. application/yang-data+json
5. name 
6. type
7. ietf:ipv4
8. ip
9.netmask

Correct answer is :

1. ietf:interfaces:interfaces
2. interface
3. Basic..
4. application/yang-data+json
5. name 
6. type
7. ietf:ipv4
8. ip
9.netmask

Correct answer is:
1 - ietf-ibterfaces:interfaces
2 - interfaces
3 - Basic
4 - Application/yang-data+json
5 - name
6 - type
7 - ietf-ip:ipv4
8 - ip
9 - netmask
Source: https://blogs.cisco.com/developer/intro-to-programmability-3

1. ietf-interfaces:interface
2. interface
3. Basic ....
4. aplication/yang-data+json
5. name
6. type
7. ietf-ipv4
8. ip
9. netmask
